title.rendered: The Civil Guard warns of a scam that supplants the DGT to pay a false fine

content.rendered:
If they get a mail which claims to be the General Directorate of Traffic (DGT), you have to be careful. The Civil Guard has warned of a new type of scam related to fake traffic tickets. Fraudsters use a fraudulent email campaignknown as a ‘phishing’ method, with which supplant the DGT.

This email lbears the logo of the entity and the Ministry of the Interiorand sends a message that reads: “You have a pending fine”, and then they put a link that takes you to the alleged notification, which of course is false.

When the victim of the scam clicks on this link, malware is automatically downloaded onto their device. Namely, a malicious program that is capable of stealing your personal and financial data. So, in this way, fraudsters can access your usernames and passwords to access all kinds of platforms and social networks, including the bank’s website.

Likewise, scammers often use this type of method during vacation times, such as during Easter, since it is common for many people to make long journeys with their vehicles on those dates. For this reason, one of the organizations that has denounced this action, the OR IF, has warned that if the ‘malware’ has been executed or simply downloaded, the device has been automatically infected. The Internet Security Office assures that, to solve this problem, it is advisable to go to the downloads folder and delete the filein addition to deleting the mail from the inbox.

In any case, once both steps are completed, the organization highlights the importance of scanning the device with an antivirus to know the real status of the device and demonstrate whether it is safe to use.
